Corn_Common_Rust.Cause: Caused by the fungus Puccinia sorghi, leading to the formation of small pustules on corn leaves.
Corn_Common_Rust.Details: Corn Common Rust results in raised, rusty lesions on corn leaves.
Corn_Common_Rust.Solutions (Traditional): Use resistant varieties, crop rotation, and proper spacing.
Corn_Common_Rust.Solutions (Modern): Apply fungicides and use resistant corn varieties.
Corn_Common_Rust.Additional Info: The disease thrives in warm and humid conditions.

Corn_Gray_Leaf_Spot.Cause: Caused by the fungus Cercospora zeae-maydis, which causes lesions on leaves.
Corn_Gray_Leaf_Spot.Details: Gray lesions with dark borders appear on corn leaves.
Corn_Gray_Leaf_Spot.Solutions (Modern): Fungicide applications and resistant corn hybrids.
Corn_Gray_Leaf_Spot.Additional Info: It affects corn during the growing season, especially in humid environments.

Corn_Healthy.Details: Corn is healthy with no visible symptoms of disease.
Corn_Healthy.Solutions (Traditional): Maintain healthy soil, regular irrigation, and proper spacing.
Corn_Healthy.Solutions (Modern): Monitor plant health using modern farming techniques and AI-based systems.
Corn_Healthy.Recommended Fertilizers: Balanced fertilizers, including nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium.
Corn_Healthy.Additional Info: Healthy corn requires optimal growth conditions and regular monitoring.

Corn_Northern_Leaf_Blight.Cause: Caused by the fungus Exserohilum turcicum, which causes long lesions on corn leaves.
Corn_Northern_Leaf_Blight.Details: Northern leaf blight causes large, elongated lesions on corn leaves.
Corn_Northern_Leaf_Blight.Additional Info: This disease thrives under cool, moist conditions.

maize_ear_rot.Cause: Caused by various fungi like Fusarium and Aspergillus, which infect the corn ears.
maize_ear_rot.Details: Fungal infection causes ear rot, leading to discolored kernels and a bad smell.
maize_ear_rot.Solutions (Traditional): Proper crop rotation and harvest management.
maize_ear_rot.Solutions (Modern): Use fungicides and control moisture levels.
maize_ear_rot.Additional Info: Ear rot commonly occurs during the wet and humid harvest periods.

maize_fall_armyworm.Cause: Caused by the insect Spodoptera frugiperda, which feeds on maize plants.
maize_fall_armyworm.Details: Fall armyworms cause damage by eating the leaves and kernels of maize.
maize_fall_armyworm.Solutions (Traditional): Manual pest control, use of natural predators.
maize_fall_armyworm.Additional Info: Fall armyworms are migratory and can cause significant crop loss.

maize_stem_borer.Cause: Caused by the insect Busseola fusca, which bores into maize stems.
maize_stem_borer.Details: Stem borers damage the maize plant by feeding on the stalks, leading to plant wilting.
maize_stem_borer.Additional Info: Stem borers are active during the growing season and can damage maize plants severely.

Cotton_Aphids.Cause: Caused by the cotton aphid Aphis gossypii, which feeds on the sap of cotton plants.
Cotton_Aphids.Details: Aphids cause yellowing and stunted growth in cotton plants.
Cotton_Aphids.Solutions (Traditional): Use of natural predators like ladybugs and neem oil.
Cotton_Aphids.Additional Info: Aphids are common during warm weather and can also transmit viruses.

Cotton_Army_worm.Cause: Caused by the insect Spodoptera litura, which feeds on cotton leaves and bolls.
Cotton_Army_worm.Details: Armyworms cause defoliation and boll damage in cotton plants.
Cotton_Army_worm.Solutions (Traditional): Manual pest control and use of natural predators.
Cotton_Army_worm.Additional Info: The armyworm is a migratory pest that can damage large areas quickly.

Cotton_Bacterial_Blight.Cause: Caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas citri pv. malvacearum, which infects cotton leaves, stems, and bolls.
Cotton_Bacterial_Blight.Details: Bacterial Blight leads to dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves and stems, eventually causing defoliation and reduced yield.
Cotton_Bacterial_Blight.Solutions (Traditional): Use resistant cotton varieties, proper crop rotation, and avoid overhead irrigation.
Cotton_Bacterial_Blight.Solutions (Modern): Apply copper-based bactericides and use disease-resistant genetically modified varieties.
Cotton_Bacterial_Blight.Recommended Fertilizers: Balanced fertilizers with adequate potassium and phosphorus.
Cotton_Bacterial_Blight.Additional Info: The disease spreads rapidly in warm, humid conditions and through infected seeds.

Cotton_Cotton_Boll_Rot.Cause: Caused by fungi such as Fusarium, which rots cotton bolls.
Cotton_Cotton_Boll_Rot.Details: Cotton boll rot leads to premature decay of the cotton bolls.
Cotton_Cotton_Boll_Rot.Solutions (Traditional): Proper irrigation and drainage, crop rotation.
Cotton_Cotton_Boll_Rot.Additional Info: The disease is more prevalent during wet conditions.

Cotton_Green_Cotton_Boll.Cause: Caused by various pathogens affecting the boll formation.
Cotton_Green_Cotton_Boll.Details: Green cotton bolls are underdeveloped and turn green rather than maturing.
Cotton_Green_Cotton_Boll.Additional Info: The condition can be linked to excessive moisture and pest infestation.

Cotton_Healthy.Cause: Healthy cotton is free from disease, pests, and nutrient deficiencies.
Cotton_Healthy.Details: Cotton plants grow vigorously with dark green leaves, proper boll formation, and high fiber quality.
Cotton_Healthy.Solutions (Traditional): Good agronomic practices, proper irrigation, and soil fertility management.
Cotton_Healthy.Solutions (Modern): Use of precision agriculture, drone-based monitoring, and integrated pest management (IPM).
Cotton_Healthy.Recommended Manures: Well-decomposed organic manure and green manure.
Cotton_Healthy.Recommended Fertilizers: Balanced NPK fertilizers based on soil test results.
Cotton_Healthy.Additional Info: Optimal temperature, irrigation, and pest control are crucial for healthy cotton growth.

Cotton_Powdery_mildew.Cause: Caused by the fungus Erysiphe cichoracearum, which forms white powdery spots on leaves and stems.
Cotton_Powdery_mildew.Details: Powdery Mildew weakens the plant by reducing photosynthesis, leading to stunted growth and lower fiber quality.
Cotton_Powdery_mildew.Solutions (Traditional): Crop rotation, proper plant spacing, and field sanitation.
Cotton_Powdery_mildew.Solutions (Modern): Use sulfur-based fungicides and resistant varieties.
Cotton_Powdery_mildew.Recommended Fertilizers: Sulfur-rich fertilizers and balanced NPK fertilizers.
Cotton_Powdery_mildew.Additional Info: The disease thrives in dry, warm conditions and spreads via airborne spores.

Cotton_Target_spot.Cause: Caused by the fungus Corynespora cassiicola, which creates brown circular lesions on leaves.
Cotton_Target_spot.Details: Target Spot reduces leaf photosynthesis, leading to premature defoliation and yield loss.
Cotton_Target_spot.Solutions (Traditional): Use resistant cotton varieties, deep plowing, and removal of infected plant debris.
Cotton_Target_spot.Solutions (Modern): Application of fungicides like azoxystrobin and proper canopy management.
Cotton_Target_spot.Recommended Fertilizers: Potassium-rich fertilizers to strengthen plant resistance.
Cotton_Target_spot.Additional Info: This disease is common in high-humidity regions and spreads via water splashes and wind.

Paddy_Bacterial_Leaf_Blight.Cause: Caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas oryzae, leading to water-soaked lesions on paddy leaves.
Paddy_Bacterial_Leaf_Blight.Details: This disease causes yellowing of leaves followed by necrosis.
Paddy_Bacterial_Leaf_Blight.Solutions (Traditional): Use resistant rice varieties and maintain proper irrigation.
Paddy_Bacterial_Leaf_Blight.Solutions (Modern): Use copper-based bactericides and AI-based monitoring.
Paddy_Bacterial_Leaf_Blight.Additional Info: A common disease in humid conditions, especially during the rainy season.

Paddy_Brown_Spot.Cause: Caused by the fungus Cochliobolus miyabeanus, which causes brown lesions on rice leaves.
Paddy_Brown_Spot.Details: Brown spots appear on rice leaves, leading to decreased photosynthesis.
Paddy_Brown_Spot.Solutions (Traditional): Crop rotation and use resistant varieties.
Paddy_Brown_Spot.Solutions (Modern): Fungicide applications and integrated pest management.
Paddy_Brown_Spot.Additional Info: The disease is common during the growing season in wet conditions.

Paddy_Healthy.Details: Paddy is free from any diseases and showing optimal growth.
Paddy_Healthy.Solutions (Modern): AI-based health monitoring and sustainable farming practices.
Paddy_Healthy.Recommended Fertilizers: Balanced fertilizers including nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium.
Paddy_Healthy.Additional Info: Healthy paddy requires optimal environmental conditions and regular monitoring.

Paddy_Leaf_Blast.Cause: Caused by the fungus Magnaporthe oryzae, which attacks rice leaves, causing diamond-shaped lesions.
Paddy_Leaf_Blast.Details: Leaf Blast severely affects photosynthesis, leading to reduced grain yield and poor plant health.
Paddy_Leaf_Blast.Solutions (Traditional): Use resistant rice varieties, avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization, and maintain proper water management.
Paddy_Leaf_Blast.Solutions (Modern): Apply systemic fungicides like tricyclazole and use remote sensing technology for early disease detection.
Paddy_Leaf_Blast.Recommended Manures: Farmyard manure and compost enriched with phosphorus.
Paddy_Leaf_Blast.Recommended Fertilizers: Balanced NPK fertilizers with controlled nitrogen levels.
Paddy_Leaf_Blast.Additional Info: The disease spreads rapidly in warm, humid conditions and is more severe in water-deficient fields.

Paddy_Leaf_Scald.Cause: Caused by the fungus Microdochium oryzae, leading to elongated brown lesions with water-soaked edges on leaves.
Paddy_Leaf_Scald.Details: Leaf Scald weakens rice plants by reducing the leaf's photosynthetic ability, causing premature drying.
Paddy_Leaf_Scald.Solutions (Traditional): Use tolerant rice varieties, maintain proper field sanitation, and ensure adequate plant spacing.
Paddy_Leaf_Scald.Solutions (Modern): Application of fungicides like propiconazole and real-time monitoring using AI-driven tools.
Paddy_Leaf_Scald.Recommended Fertilizers: Potassium-rich fertilizers to enhance disease resistance.
Paddy_Leaf_Scald.Additional Info: It spreads under warm, wet conditions and is commonly observed in densely planted fields.

Paddy_Sheath_Blight.Cause: Caused by the fungus Rhizoctonia solani, which infects the rice stem sheaths, causing water-soaked lesions.
Paddy_Sheath_Blight.Details: Sheath Blight weakens plant structure, reducing grain filling and overall yield.
Paddy_Sheath_Blight.Solutions (Traditional): Use disease-resistant varieties, avoid excessive nitrogen use, and ensure proper plant spacing.
Paddy_Sheath_Blight.Solutions (Modern): Apply fungicides like hexaconazole and integrate biological control using Trichoderma species.
Paddy_Sheath_Blight.Additional Info: The disease spreads through infected soil and plant debris and thrives in warm, humid conditions.

Paddy_Tungro.Cause: Caused by a combination of Rice Tungro Bacilliform Virus (RTBV) and Rice Tungro Spherical Virus (RTSV), transmitted by leafhoppers.
Paddy_Tungro.Details: Tungro causes stunted growth, yellow-orange discoloration of leaves, and reduced tillering in paddy plants.
Paddy_Tungro.Solutions (Traditional): Use resistant rice varieties, remove infected plants, and maintain field sanitation.
Paddy_Tungro.Solutions (Modern): Control vector (leafhoppers) using insecticides and adopt virus-free nursery practices.
Paddy_Tungro.Recommended Manures: Compost, green manure, and well-decomposed farmyard manure.
Paddy_Tungro.Recommended Fertilizers: Balanced fertilizers, especially nitrogen and potassium, to support recovery.
Paddy_Tungro.Additional Info: The disease spreads rapidly through leafhopper vectors, especially in warm and humid conditions. Early detection and vector control are crucial.

SugarCane_BacterialBlights.Cause: Caused by various bacteria such as Xanthomonas, which infect sugarcane plants.
SugarCane_BacterialBlights.Details: Bacterial blights lead to dark lesions and stunted growth in sugarcane.
SugarCane_BacterialBlights.Solutions (Modern): Copper-based bactericides and modern disease detection methods.
SugarCane_BacterialBlights.Additional Info: Bacterial blights thrive in warm, humid conditions.

SugarCane_Healthy.Details: Sugar cane is healthy, free from any visible disease symptoms.
SugarCane_Healthy.Solutions (Traditional): Regular irrigation, healthy soil, and good crop management.
SugarCane_Healthy.Solutions (Modern): Use of AI-based monitoring systems and precision agriculture.
SugarCane_Healthy.Recommended Fertilizers: Balanced fertilizers with nitrogen and potassium.
SugarCane_Healthy.Additional Info: Healthy sugar cane requires good management practices and optimal environmental conditions.

SugarCane_Mosaic.Cause: Caused by the Sugarcane Mosaic Virus (SCMV), leading to yellow mottling on leaves.
SugarCane_Mosaic.Details: Mosaic virus causes yellowing and stunted growth in sugarcane.
SugarCane_Mosaic.Solutions (Traditional): Use resistant varieties and control aphids.
SugarCane_Mosaic.Solutions (Modern): Viral control through resistance breeding and modern pest management.
SugarCane_Mosaic.Additional Info: Mosaic virus is spread by aphids and can reduce sugarcane yields significantly.

SugarCane_RedRot.Cause: Caused by the fungus Glomerella tucumanensis, leading to rotting of sugarcane stalks.
SugarCane_RedRot.Details: Red rot leads to the breakdown of stalks, causing plant death.
SugarCane_RedRot.Solutions (Traditional): Avoid waterlogging and practice crop rotation.
SugarCane_RedRot.Additional Info: Red rot is prevalent in areas with poor drainage and wet conditions.

SugarCane_Rust.Cause: Caused by the fungus Puccinia melanocephala, which forms reddish-brown pustules on sugarcane leaves.
SugarCane_Rust.Details: Rust weakens the plant by reducing photosynthesis, leading to lower sugar content and yield loss.
SugarCane_Rust.Solutions (Traditional): Use resistant sugarcane varieties, proper field sanitation, and crop rotation.
SugarCane_Rust.Solutions (Modern): Apply fungicides like tebuconazole and use early disease detection through remote sensing.
SugarCane_Rust.Recommended Fertilizers: Balanced fertilizers with sufficient potassium to enhance disease resistance.
SugarCane_Rust.Additional Info: The disease spreads through airborne spores and thrives in warm, humid conditions.

SugarCane_Yellow.Cause: Caused by the Sugarcane Yellow Leaf Virus (SCYLV), transmitted by aphids.
SugarCane_Yellow.Details: Yellow Leaf Disease leads to yellowing of the midrib, reduced plant vigor, and significant yield loss.
SugarCane_Yellow.Solutions (Traditional): Use virus-free planting material, control aphid populations, and maintain proper field hygiene.
SugarCane_Yellow.Solutions (Modern): Apply biological control agents for aphids and use virus-resistant sugarcane varieties.
SugarCane_Yellow.Recommended Manures: Well-rotted organic compost and green manure.
SugarCane_Yellow.Recommended Fertilizers: Nitrogen and potassium-rich fertilizers to strengthen plant immunity.
SugarCane_Yellow.Additional Info: The disease spreads through infected planting material and aphid vectors.
